metadata.title: Technological change and wage premiums: Historical evidence from linked employer-employee data

relevance.relevance: The study examines the impact of the steam engine on wage premiums, highlighting the polarizing effects of technological change on labor markets, which is directly relevant to the field of labor displacement due to technological change.

design.sample_characteristics: Swedish merchant mariners from six port towns: Gävle, Härnösand, Hudiksvall, Karlskrona, Söderhamn, and Visby.

dependent_variables.wage_changes: High-skilled and unskilled laborers improved their relative wage positions, while intermediate-skilled laborers saw a decline.

text_fragments: The steam technology had both new skill-demanding and skill-replacing aspects.
High-skilled and unskilled labourers improved their relative wage positions.
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study describes the transition from sail to steam technology in the maritime industry and its impact on occupational structures and wage distributions.

historical_context.economic_conditions: Period of industrialisation and economic growth in Sweden.
historical_context.institutional_context: The maritime industry was a small part of the Swedish economy, influenced by broader industrialisation trends.

outcomes.main_findings: The steam engine led to wage polarisation, benefiting high-skilled and unskilled workers while disadvantaging intermediate-skilled workers.
outcomes.conclusions: The study concludes that technological change, specifically the steam engine, had a polarising effect on the labor market, increasing wage inequality.
